question_text: MS pathophysiology is most commonly associated with which of the following?

options.A: EBV

question_text: Which risk factor has an odds ratio of 0.5 and is considered unknown in its association with multiple sclerosis?

options.A: Oral tobacco

question_text: An MS patient developed a tremor. What is the recommended treatment?

options.A: Propranolol

question_text: In a case of testicular cancer, which antibody is most likely to be present?

options.A: Anti-MA
patient with optic neuritis and one periventricular lesion. What is her McDonald criteria?
female patient came with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) and an attached MRI of the brain and spine. What is the mechanism of the disease?

patient diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS) continues to experience relapses despite starting disease-modifying therapy (DMT). The spinal cord MRI shows a "trident sign." What is the most likely diagnosis?
patient with a long history of multiple sclerosis presents with fatigue. What medication would you consider as a first-line treatment?
patient receiving their third infusion of Natalizumab develops an allergy with shortness of breath. What should be done?

question_text: Which factor is associated with a worse prognosis in multiple sclerosis (MS)?

options.A: Male sex

question_text: Patient came with focal seizure with secondary generalization; he has focal atrophy in the brain; what is the antibody associated with this disease?

options.A: GluR3

question_text: In a paraneoplastic case, what should be done next?

options.A: Treat underlying etiology
patient with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) received 5 days of intravenous methylprednisolone (IVMP) without improvement. What should be done next?

question_text: An MS patient developed tonic spasms. What is the appropriate treatment?

options.A: Carbamazepine
patient with multiple sclerosis experiences painful muscle spasms multiple times per day. Which medication is commonly used for this condition?

question_text: Which of the following indicates disease progression in multiple sclerosis (MS)?

options.A: Brain atrophy

patient presented with focal seizures that progressed to complex partial seizures and multiple episodes of status epilepticus with hemiparesis. MRI showed hemispheric perisylvian atrophy. What will you send for?

question_text: Patient came with focal seizure with secondary generalization; he has focal atrophy in the brain. What is the antibody associated with this disease?

options.A: GluR3

question_text: In a scenario involving diabetes mellitus with stiff person syndrome, what is the most likely antibody present?

options.A: Anti-GAD

question_text: Which condition is based on astrocyte pathology?

options.A: NMOSD

question_text: What is known about the pathology of multiple sclerosis (MS)?

options.A: Diffuse white matter disease and focal grey matter involvement
options.B: Grey matter disease may be related to a progressive course
